raw_response: {"answer_index": 3, "answer_text": "All of the above", "confidence": 9, "reasoning": "Apical periodontitis is inflammation of the periapical tissues. While the most common cause is pulpal necrosis/disease (sequel of pulpal diseases), it can also result from trauma including wedging of foreign objects between teeth and occlusal trauma from high points in restorations. Since all three listed options can cause apical periodontitis, 'All of the above' is the correct answer. The student's answer of only 'High points in restoration' is incomplete as it excludes the other valid causes."}
